higher liquidity markets distributed across brokers and exchanges is how to solve it. For example, as a client you can plug into multiple MT5 brokers or crypto exchanges simultaneously & split your funds across them to optimize order filling using what we’re building. 

In general, forex markets daily volume is in the trillions, btc and eth are continuously climbing. It’s why we don’t allow low liq markets.

I thought the same too, yet currently with dale only automated option on one cex only, better use lower balance to avoid imprecise trade execution. I'll start with low to mid 5 fig balance with them and see how it performs.

About the scalable platform you mentioned earlier today, any eta for it?

Yup exactly why I said start small with Dale. We’re still in the early stages of PTN. Building the systems to execute at scale on its information takes time to build. I know Dale is also expanding to more exchanges to allow more copy trading options. The platform we’re building is meant to take PTN to scale with billions in volume from clients.

I don’t want to ruin surprises and all the work our team is doing behind the scenes for it but you can expect Q3.

Looking forward to it.

Using the native incentive mechanism as a trading system, we can capture their gains while reducing the risk from their positions when they hit drawdowns.  Not only that, their new drawdown works against them for 30 days so theyre deprioritized by the network, and if they hit a 5% drawdown they get 0 incentive.

the mechanisms in place have been reviewed extensively by our community, @Terps for example being one who is very active. We are constantly listening for feedback, and we even have a full proposal process for our community to review before we commit changes.

the whole goal of the SN is get a balanced approach based on unique strategies, & reduce risk based on the native incentive mechanism while capturing gains. I think it does it quite well, and would welcome counter arguments based on full review of the incentive mechanism.

There is a place for legitimate criticism.  If a subnet has significant issues about how it's designed, or if there are vulnerabilities, it does need to be discussed in the open. If you will not accept people's answers, though, don't continue banging the drum.  Instead, accept that this might not be the place for you.

However, in all cases, these things need to be discussed in a civil manner.  If you are aggressive or accusatory in the way that you talk about those problems ("maliciousness or incompetence") -- if you're coming from a place that assumes that the people involved are either scammers or idiots and you treat them this way from the start, then you should not expect to be entitled to a forum here.   

If you cannot express your issues with a particular subnet, its code, or its developers in a way that is not insulting or accusatory then you won't be able to participate in the Opentensor Foundation's Discord.  I realize that the development of social media prioritizes sarcasm, snark, and one-liners over actual civil human discourse, but if that's the only way you know how to communicate, you'll need to do it on Twitter/X (or some other platform that accepts that kind of behavior) and not here.

@ptn・8  On the topic of legitimate criticism, we’ve got another proposal for you! We would love to get your feedback on what we see as an incremental improvement to the scoring function. This proposal addresses two components:

1. Penalties will explicitly drop the incentive of the miner to 0, instead of impacting their returns prior to incentive scoring. This will help fix the loophole where drawdown miners were scoring more highly than some miners with negative returns. 
2. We will limit the distribution of incentive to the top 25 miners. Currently our top 10 miners provide almost all of the usable signals on the network. We want to prioritize them for their contributions, and disengage miners who provide no value. To do this, we will provide miners outside of the top 25 with 0 incentive, and use a maximum of 25 miners in the exponential decay.

Details can be found here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/11dcaT1jWRa2401Sc8WDOnSHkX5qkLKCs7NdzXFIl1OI/edit?usp=sharing
PR can be found here: https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/pull/245

We hope to have this delivered by Jun 22, 2024. Looking forward to your feedback.

@Whit_Delta We could also do this- the exponential curve currently adjusts for the number of the miners in the system. We have a 30 day ramp in period for challenge and plan to keep even if we eventually transition away from challenge, which gives miners a small benefit as they ramp in. TARVIS is an incredibly sophisticated and calculated trading strategy that took 2 years of development time built based on models of the market. It's not a simple bot, nor is it simple to explain. I'd like to now jump into the conversation of miner who are performing martingale strategies, how our incentive mechanism works, and what we're hoping to achieve. 

I also appreciate the question as to why a strategy that **is** using a martingale strategy isn't something that we're specifically targeting. This is something we've been analyzing internally, and as I announced in previous posts, is an ongoing investigation. We do not want to rush to a decision, as we have reason to believe that our incentive mechanism is fully capable of handling the needs of the strategy we're building and properly derisking off any miner.

Let's start with some basic terminology:

returns - gains by the miner
drawdown - losses
mid-trade drawdown - losses in the middle of their trade 

I'll take a step back and explain, what is the strategy we're building and what are we trying to achieve?

The beautiful part of PTN is that miners are constantly competing to provide high returns, low mid-trade drawdowns, consistent performances, **and they have to be continuously doing that over long periods of time**. If a miner fails to continue to provide returns, their incentive begins to slip as theyre not a recent producer. Because the incentive mechanism is analyzing miners on a second to second basis bsaed on their mid-trade performance, we are able to dynamically change their incentive in near real-time. If the miner begins to slip into a larger losing trade their incentive starts to drop immediately and they're naturally deprioritized by the network.

This has all been built with great intention, as the incentive mechanism is the backbone for a strategy that we're building. The strategy uses the incentive mechanism of each miner for the purposes of determining their portfolio usage of a strategy. You can imagine a portfolio which sums to a value of 1. Each miner receiving incentive would be a piece of that portfolio based on their trades, as incentive also sums to 1. This allows us to have a balanced strategy, where we're not leaning heavily on any single miner, we're able to leverage the performance of the top performing miners, and we can create a strategy that can dynamically shift based on changes in performance.

Let's walk through a concrete and specific example based on a made up miner:

Let's say "Miner 1" has 11% of the incentive of the network, their trades would make up 11% of the portfolio balance of this strategy. Miner 1 would have to be doing extremely well to get placed here, so lets say hypothetically theyre providing 3% returns and 1% mid-trade drawdown. They've been extremely consistent in how they've provided those returns over a 30 day period, meaning they're constantly providing returns (not just hitting 1 big trade over 5 minutes). This miner would be one of the top miners on the network.

Now let's say that miner's performance starts to slip, and they start entering an unfavorable position where their mid-trade drawdown starts to get out of hand. Let's say their mid-trade drawdown starts sliding from .3%, to .6% mid-trade, deviating from historical performance. Because we're monitoring for instantaneous changes in near real-time performance, and because of how significant recent returns are, that miner's incentive drops hard. They would no longer be a top miner, they would be seeinga heavy slide down to 30th+ in incentive, eventually fully deprioritized by the network. 

Now, how would this impact the trading strategy? The trading strategy has already captured the positive returns by this miner (3%) and has in near real-time begun deprioritizing the positional size of this miner as its tied to their incentive. As the miner's incentive drops, so does the positional size. The impact of this poor position by the miner would not even be fully realized as their positional size would be dropped to near 0. The strategy would have effectively received all of the benefits of the miner, while mitigating the downside risk of the position. It may take a small drawdown (0.1-0.2%), but its countering that with 3% previous returns, ensuring user's portfolios of the strategy have little impact. 

As you can imagine, the scenario I just provided also encapsulates a martingale strategy which begins to implode. Their incentive drops to 0, they would get deprioritized by the network, and the strategy would have little impact.

Now let's look at specific example of this actually occurring with this miner who does use a martingale strategy:

Lets zone in on 6/12 when we begin to see the slide in performance and the increase in drawdown. I've provided as screenshots (attached below) the performance of this miner from our dashboard and also their incentive from taostats, both links can be found here:

taostats incentive - https://x.taostats.io/hotkey/5G3ys2356ovgUivX3endMP7f37LPEjRkzDAM3Km8CxQnErCw
actual performance from dashboard - https://dashboard.taoshi.io/miner/5G3ys2356ovgUivX3endMP7f37LPEjRkzDAM3Km8CxQnErCw
Hi @Arrash [τ, τ] thanks for the informed response

You can see how quickly their incentive starts to drop even **at the beginning when they start to lose control of their trade** on the 12th. On the 12th by itself they had already significantly lost positioning, and by the 14th they were one of the **worst performing miners on the entire network in terms of incentive.** Up to this point, this miner had already provided us ~5% returns, and on the 14th they had 0.7% drawdown which wouldn't have been fully realized as their incentive was so drastically falling. Therefore, we would have effectively taken their returns while mitigating their mid-trade drawdown risk. 

As you can see, this doesn't just handle martingale strategies, but **all** strategies that begin to slide in performance, there is no need to single out just martingale. And with a properly working incentive mechanism, we can effecitvely reduce positional risk on miners if they perform poorly while retaining their gains.

I'd also like to add that @Thomas | Taoshi [τ, θ]  has been working non-stop on analyzing how we can make fine tune incentive even more to better handle these scenarios, and is doing a full analysis of this specific miner, how we would retain their historical returns while reducing impact from their recent losses. He'll be following up shortly with that full analysis. 

Please let me know if you have any questions.

We have done analysis, @Thomas | Taoshi [τ, θ] has already performed this on the top 20 miners on the network (which compose over 90% of network miner emissions). We'll provide the analysis and even more in depth information and thoughts on miners, martingale, how are incentive mechanism mitigates any high-risk strategy, and the questions we think are significant shortly.

Hey @consτ [τ, τ] , thanks for the questions. As Arrash highlighted, a single miner scaling into a losing position will result in higher drawdowns and thus taper them out of system weights. We haven't seen evidence of this on a system wide level or from top miners, who would control the aggregated output of the system assuming we use their weights to inform a weighted average output. The top 20 miners currently receive 92% of network weight. There are 2 who use derivatives of martingale: 5G3ys2356ovgUivX3 and MP7f37LPEjRkzDAM3Km8CxQnErCw and 5GhRAbtoaXXvkZKz8v7RiqRYy8omY5jpEtd1vTcHW1owH4gt. Together they compose 6.1 + 0.0793 of network miner emissions or 6.17% of emissions.

As Arrash mentioned, when their behavior deviates from their prior with MDD, their score will reflect this as seen by the example miner. Their score can be thought of as their network aggregate impact, meaning that as their drawdown increases, we will shed their positions from an aggregate strategy, such that even if they take a 5% drawdown, the network will not assume this full loss as it will proportionally decrease the size of the positions when the miner's weights drop. If these miners assume 6.17% of network emissions and take drawdown in synchronous, their drawdown impact on system outputs would therefore be at max 6.17% * 0.1 = 0.62%. More realistically it will be closer to 0.3% as we already shed their positions as they began to take drawdown.

The issue with martingale is runaway leverage usage - this is not unique to martingale, but something our incentive will always disincentivize. A naive martingale strategy will likely have erratic drawdown values, which already works against the miner prior to the 5% limit as new peaks on drawdown values effectively reduce the prior gains captured. A martingale strategy which limits its risk exposure by closing losing positions as they begin to assume drawdown is not penalized by us, but also no longer martingale.

Our incentive currently captures the upside of trading activity, and effectively de-risks the miners as their behavior becomes erratic. Regardless of the strategy, we penalize erratic downside risk in real time, martingale included. Because of this, we don't explicitly need to target the behavior of a specific strategy as long as we have other strong miners on the network who will fill their void in network incentive.

I'm working on a more in depth analysis on dynamics of how martingale approaches would impact our overall system weights, and will release that as a blog post for the community as soon as it's finished. In general, as our top miners are aware, consistency in never passing a drawdown value between 0.25%MDD and 1.5%MDD is the best way to effectively reduce penalties - in doing so we are able to compare the pure quality of signal from each miner as a ratio of reward to risk.

If through our analysis we discover a disproportionate benefit is provided to exponential risk utilization through strategies such as naive martingale, we will design and build into our subnet a mechanism to detect and remove them. However, in our view, this is directly reducing the returns we can provide our clients, and harming our end product.

@Arrash [τ, τ]  @Thomas | Taoshi [τ, θ] 

There are some other metrics which could be used to evaluate the risk/reward of a trading strategy:

```markdown
Sharpe Ratio: Measures the risk-adjusted return of an investment. It is calculated by taking the difference between the portfolio return and the risk-free rate, and dividing it by the portfolio's standard deviation.

Sortino Ratio: Similar to the Sharpe Ratio, but it only considers downside risk (negative volatility) rather than total volatility.

Maximum Drawdown (MDD): The maximum observed loss from a peak to a trough of a portfolio, before a new peak is achieved. It measures the largest drop in value during a specific period.

Calmar Ratio: The ratio of the average annual return to the maximum drawdown. It helps to understand the risk-reward profile of a trading strategy.

Win Rate: The percentage of trades that are profitable. It gives an indication of the consistency of the strategy.

Profit Factor: The ratio of gross profit to gross loss. A profit factor greater than 1 indicates a profitable system.

Alpha: Measures the performance of an investment relative to a market index or benchmark. Positive alpha indicates outperformance, while negative alpha indicates underperformance.

Beta: Measures the volatility of an investment relative to the market as a whole. A beta greater than 1 indicates more volatility than the market, while a beta less than 1 indicates less volatility.

R-squared: Indicates how closely a trading strategy's returns are correlated to the market's returns. An R-squared close to 1 suggests a strong correlation.

Value at Risk (VaR): Estimates the maximum potential loss over a specified time period with a given confidence level. It's a measure of the potential risk.

Expected Shortfall (ES) / Conditional Value at Risk (CVaR): Measures the average loss in the worst-case scenario (beyond the VaR threshold).

Trade Expectancy: The average amount one can expect to win or lose per trade. It is calculated as (Probability of Win * Average Win) - (Probability of Loss * Average Loss).

Information Ratio: Measures the returns of the strategy in excess of the benchmark, adjusted by the standard deviation of these excess returns.

Treynor Ratio: Similar to the Sharpe Ratio but uses beta instead of standard deviation in the denominator. It assesses how much return was generated for each unit of market risk.

Consistency Metrics: Such as the percentage of profitable months or the percentage of time the strategy stays above its benchmar
```

There are products launched like Dale based on PTN, but they are not using the network strategy. They are pulling from a group of miners, or specific miners on the network to decide their trading strategy.

The miners are very performant shown by just how much interest Dale ($500k in assets under management), Taopey, and Timeless' TG channel (2k users who've joined their TG channel) are garnering, but we need more time to develop the exact performance of the overall network strategy. That is something that we're concentrating our efforts on this very moment. 

* How do we derisk from miners? 
* What does derisking look like when modeled out? 
* What does a network strategy like look combining and derisking off these miners when backtested?
* What does performance look like based on sharpe, sortino, profit factor, win rate, and PTN's incentive mechanism accounting for risk adjusted returns? 

These are all questions we are looking to answer and we've already started investigation with blog posts, but we also recognize its critical we make our core logic and incentive mechanism more robust with some needed features.

We have 3 main features we're adding over June and July that will help us finalize the network strategy and get the exact performance we're looking for. 

1. **funding based fees** - we run SN8 like a pseudo futures based exchange, therefore miners will be charged for keeping their positions open for longer periods of time making it align more with what our clients expect in terms of fees based on contracts, swap fees, funding rates on brokers & exchanges
2. **extending performance lookback from 30 days to 60 days** - we want to increase the period in which we judge performance of miners from a 30 day lookback to a 60 day lookback, which will give us more information to determine performance of miners for incentive purposes, which will in turn also impact the way we handle our network strategy. This may continue to extend in time. This will also allow us to further extend the timeout period where a miner's incentive is set to 0 for crossing 5% mdd.
3. **reducing max leverage on a per miner basis** - we are going to implement a feature where there is a max leverage a miner can use across all their positions at once. This will help us better risk manage from our miners for the purposes of the network strategy.

Once these are finalized, we believe creating the network strategy will be fully realized.

Just context on how we roll out features. Every one of these features first goes through a proposal process from our team to our very active community. We then go through potentially multiple rounds of feedback and iteration. From there we reach agreement on the proposal, and we begin tech designing and implementation. The proposals for all of the features are currently being worked on.

Hi @ptn・8 , I'm happy to share some analysis we've been doing behind the scenes. This format is new for Taoshi, and this documentation website will serve as the platform for future updates on proposals and system level analysis–any feedback is appreciated.

Our objective with SN8 is to incentivize miner behavior so that a weighted average of their positions, based on current incentives, can generate a highly effective trading strategy known as the Network Model. To protect the Network Model from high risk and ensure consistent miner behavior before scoring, our incentive mechanism utilizes maximum drawdown to standardize miner scores before distributing incentives. To illustrate the effectiveness of our max drawdown penalty, we conducted simulations involving several top miners by introducing an exponentially increasing Martingale position. We found that our miners can capture potential gains from the position while maintaining reasonable leverage, but they are pruned off from the system’s incentives once their leverage usage becomes abnormal. This protects our aggregated network strategy from high drawdown exposure, thereby minimizing system-level risk. It's important to note that each miner’s normal behavior is uniquely defined based on their historical drawdown usage. As such, their incentive response from the network for the same position may vary.

Results on our analysis can be found here: https://docs.taoshi.io/strategy/runawayrisk/

Hi @Thomas | Taoshi [τ, θ], could you explain (or point me to the part of the code) how returns are calculated for short positions?

@antimaniac | Allan We use positions to determine the change in portfolio value every second, it has the same logic for LONG and SHORT positions. For open positions, the following code is used to evaluate the unrealized gains:
https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/blob/33fc7c5116f2add0644a4ed290813805011753cc/vali_objects/position.py#L205

Here is the script used to track portfolio return against all positions:
https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/blob/33fc7c5116f2add0644a4ed290813805011753cc/vali_objects/vali_dataclasses/perf_ledger.py#L404C9-L404C38

Generally, we look at the position price delta and multiply it by the leverage (with some slight adjustment for fees). If the position price delta is negative this indicates the price has dropped. A negative leverage signifies a SHORT position. Multiplication of two negative terms would indicate the miner correctly predicted the drop and tracked a positive gain (increase to returns).

@ptn・8 Want to revisit the proposal for an update to scoring (P3) and address some of the great feedback we received:

Q: Why not just make the curve steeper towards the top? @Whit_Delta 
A: Setting a threshold for incentive on the top miners allows us to guarantee a level of incentive for top miners regardless of the number of miners registered. It also allows us to better facilitate the deregistration of miners, as their incentive will explicitly be set to 0 instead of an incremental value. This will help open more spots for new miners, and ensure that challenge period miners are prioritized over 0 incentive miners.

Q: What if there are more than 25 valuable miners? Might this be changed again at a later date? @Mango 
A: It’s possible this could happen. 25 was determined based on an estimated number of valuable miners currently in our system, which may need to be updated as more talent enters the subnet. To be more competitive, miners will likely adopt the strategy of trading against multiple (all all) asset classes, increasing the information density for each unique miner. Having more weight on the top lets us put more competitive pressure on the top rankings to build this type of behavior - this is really our goal here.

In response to your feedback, we propose to set the number of miners to a limit of 50 instead of 25, and increase the steepness of the curve. Instead of the top 40 percent of miners getting 90 percent of incentive, we propose the top 15 percent get 90 percent of the incentive. Beyond the 50th ranking, the miners would receive zero incentive. The updated curve is also shown in the post on our docs page, along with the full details of the proposal. Updated target release date is June 26, 2024.

No worries at all- The miner's max drawdown will likely give an intuition as to the leverage multiplier, so if the miner's max drawdown is 2% and your personal risk tolerance is 1% mdd, you might want to halve the leverage on each trade. You've got the right intuition, although perhaps more as a percentage of the portfolio instead of discrete position sizes. A 0.2x position will always move with 20% of the portfolio value, regardless of prior accumulated gains. This allows any miner regardless of prior success to track the same gains using the same leverage at any moment, which is what's used for scoring in our system.

Different trade pairs will use different leverages, typically you might see higher leverage usage in forex due to lower volatility.

@ptn・8 We have a few updates to share. Our third proposal, P3, has received positive feedback, and we are preparing for its imminent rollout. However, we see room for further enhancements and want to continue iterating before its final release. To this end, P3 will be divided into two segments: the first, an update to the application of penalties, will be released today. The second, an update to incentives, will align with the objectives of P3 and will be detailed in an upcoming proposal.

Additionally, we are introducing a new proposal, P4, aimed at managing cost-of-carry fees on our platform. This initiative seeks to reflect real-world exchange dynamics by incorporating a cost for holding a position. While the subnet may not perfectly replicate real trading environments, it is designed to provide a sufficiently challenging scenario for miners, enabling them to curate valuable products for our clients. Consequently, our trading ecosystem might present even greater challenges than a real exchange.

Our proposal is to use static values to model the approximate costs from various exchanges, reflecting the respective fee structures and timing for different asset classes. Unlike a real exchange, our fees will always reduce the position's returns and will not update dynamically. This approach avoids the complications and potential failures associated with multiple API calls, which can be costly and complex to set up. The full proposal provides a detailed explanation of the implementation and the specific values employed. Note that this will be a forward-looking update, impacting only future miner scores. We look forward to hearing your feedback.

messages.content:
I want to make a Dale-style bot, and like I've mentioned before, I am 95% of the way there (along with a whole infrastructure I've used before for botting on many exchanges).

However, I don't like how risk is dealt with, I hope someone can tell me I'm miss-understanding.  There is nothing stopping miners from doubling down until they win or the leverage maxes out (at 20x now).  Sure they'll be dis-incentivized after the trade, but what if the top martingale miner starts with super low leverage and ends up on a really bad losing streak, starting with less than 0.001 leverage, but losing 15 times in a row makes the leverage huge in the end.  This 1 bad position could wipe out the miner, along with PTN consumers/copy traders.

I have read the runaway risk document you guys put together- thank you for that.  I can see how you can catch many martingales before they implode, by using effective risk adjusted ratios.  However it doesn't seem like it would catch the miner who has done well with martingales using small leverage and then eventually ends up with a very bad position that they keep doubling down on.  The mechanism would seem to rely on chance, we're hoping that a martingale miner doesn't lose 10 times in a row, and instead only loses 7 times in a row first, thereby making their drawdown visible to the network so that they're disincentivized before they lose the 20x leverage trade.

Please help me by answering these questions directly:
1. Then is there anything stopping a miner from martingaling other than drawdown disincentive?
2. Is there a way we can see traders that have already destroyed their accounts via martingaling (or any other means)?  I don't think I get to see them via PTN.

Bonus points for this one:
3. I would propose the type of trading I was taught in @Honey Badger 's course, where traders provide:
a) entry (market price to begin with is fine)
b) stop loss
c) take profit
and the only action traders can take afterwards is closing trades that haven't hit the above targets.
This would allow PTN consumers to choose their own max risk (I would use 0.25%MR per trade but someone else might choose 1%) and make it so that there's 0 chance of martingales in the network.  It would also be clearly valuable instead of the nebulous fears of martingales we're having.

4. (even more bonus) Hire me and I'll build out (3) 😄

For now, in order for me to responsibly continue my bot's development, i've had to do my own analysis of the miners and i'll be selecting them based on my own criteria.  I do see miners (including tarvis) increasing their leverage from small positions to larger ones, I realize that this is potentially a fine trading strategy as the algorithm gains confidence, but it's also what you'd see from a martingale strategy.

I don't know how you can provide confidence that there's no martingales other than using a different trading-strategy-structure; like 3rd point above.

I have a lot of respect for you guys, you clearly have the best interest of the network at heart- as demonstrated by building PTN.  So I hope this doesn't come off like an attack.

Hey @τravis | τAO τemplar  not at all, always welcome to hear more feedback and appreciate the concern. A note on how the current risk normalization process works, and I’ll touch on how our current roadmap will interact with risk.

Our drawdown normalization looks at the ratio of returns to drawdown. If a miner starts with super low leverage (say 0.001x positions), they will likely also have incredibly low drawdown. Note that below 0.2% MDD, your score is penalized to 0, so we can assume for this that the miner starts at 0.2% MDD. Any time your drawdown doubles (which will happen as you double down into a position), your effective risk adjusted return will drop by 50%. That means from 0.2% MDD to 0.4% you will take on 50% loss, again from 0.4 to 0.8, again from 0.8 to 1.6, meaning that your effective score in our system from 0.2% MDD to 1.6% MDD would be almost 90% reduction in your risk adjusted returns.

If a miner has a strategy resembling martingale but sets a stop loss for themselves to never cross a threshold and avoid the additional drawdown penalty (let’s say 1% MDD), then I hope you’ll agree that this does not have the same risk association as a martingale.

This interacts with some of the points on our roadmap (https://docs.taoshi.io/roadmaps/july2024/) in a couple of ways:
1. We are going to set limits on the amount of leverage a miner can assume on their portfolio. This would explicitly prohibit over-utilization of resources from a single miner by capping the level of influence they might have on the network model.
2. We will look to increase the significance of long term returns in miner rankings and expand the look back window from 30 days to 90 days. This will increase the severity of our drawdown penalty by carrying it with the miner for a longer period of time, and reduce the probability that a lucky streak with a martingale approach is competitive prior to taking heavy drawdown.

Lots of confusion comes from not understanding everything is calculated in real-time* on a portfolio basis not trade basis.  'Sure they'll be dis-incentivized after the trade'. Your drawdown is calculated in real-time from your portfolio high water mark, not on a trade to trade basis. 
RE: stop loss / take profit: these things are mainly for execution not risk management, using a SL order re-shapes the distribution of your edge, if you believe in your edge you want your model to fully express the distribution you've identified. also nothing is stopping you from creating these order types within PTN yourself.

**To the Bittensor Community,** @ptn・8 
We are aware of the recent exploit affecting several subnets within the Bittensor community. We want to reassure you that Taoshi’s Proprietary Trading Network, Subnet 8 (SN8), has not been directly impacted by this issue. Our team has implemented rigorous version control protocols to help prevent such vulnerabilities.

**__Key Points:__**
1. **Strict Version Control:** We adhere to strict version control for the Bittensor package version used on our miners and validators. This ensures thorough scrutiny of new versions before implementation.
2. **Unaffected Versions:** SN8 did not use the compromised version 6.12.2 of the Bittensor package. Instead, we maintained version 6.9.3 and transitioned directly to version 7.1.0.
3. **Cautious Upgrades:** We exercise caution with version updates and will implement strict versioning for all packages, including non-BT packages, to bolster our security posture.

__**Recommendations for Subnet 8 Participants:**__
1. **Reused Keys: **If your miner or validator reuses keys with another subnet that utilized the impacted version 6.12.2, it is advisable to migrate to new wallets for asset security. Further guidance on this matter will be provided directly by the Opentensor Foundation (OTF).

__**Information for Subnet 8 Participants:**__
1. **Trade Signal Availability:** SN8 continues to receive and distribute trade signals, available for download through regular channels.
2. **TAO rewards: **Miners and validators are currently not receiving TAO. Incentives will resume once Opentensor resumes normal operation. No action is required.

We are dedicated to upholding the highest standards of security and reliability across our subnetwork. These proactive measures illustrate our commitment to safeguarding our community against potential threats.

Thank you for your continued trust and cooperation.

Sincerely,

The Taoshi Team

so there’s a few things some of these are already roadmapped in the doc, some are being added.. 

1. updating min/max leverage usage. We’ll be providing this update soon in a proposal. The min/max values for leverage will tighten per trade pair, making martingale far less effective if not impossible to use on the network. This is something you pointed out. (expected proposal out tomorrow)

2. updated fees so we address funding based fees from overnight / swaps. (roadmapped, proposal out)

3. incentive based on a 90 day lookback window. It gives us more data/touchpoints on miners. (roadmapped)

4. consistency over the 90 day lookback. The miner has to effectively perform the same actions over split windows over the 90 day lookback. (roadmapped)

5. max available leverage per miner. This is to reduce overall risk on a per miner basis. (roadmapped)

6. per position review. Recognizing the miners per position historical performance in terms of R/R over the lookback period & continued ongoing consistent performance. (being roadmapped)

Honestly, why not just use another metric like information ratio or sharpe ratio. It is quite standard in quant finance to use this. If a person has a martingale strategy then it is most likely that their strategy will have more volatility as well.

@putsncalls We plan to make these ratios available for each miner on the dashboard, to help track with intuition. We're also updating our fee structure soon, which should encourage more miners to close positions. As miners are evaluated based on unrealized portfolio value change, they currently don't need to close positions in order to score well, which makes evaluation with positional metrics challenging. This update to fees will make metrics like the Sharpe ratio more reflective of miner performance. However, this won't solve the issue with Martingale strategies, as they tend to score very well until they eventually implode, particularly on a per position basis. Limiting the minimum and maximum leverage as a first step offers several advantages for risk management- I'll be releasing a proposal soon with more information.

@ptn・8 Thanks for the segue folks. We are pleased to announce the release of Proposal Five, which outlines new limits on leverage usage per position.

Our prior analysis has demonstrated that by adjusting the leverage of miners experiencing significant losses, the system can protect itself from high drawdowns mid-trade. In this proposal, we examine the likelihood of a high-risk miner achieving incentives on the platform before experiencing a collapse. We discuss potential strategies for mitigating the probability of success prior to a blowout and present our proposed solution along with a brief analysis of its anticipated impact.

The new proposed leverage limits are designed based on the typical behavior of some of our top miners, and with other roadmap items in mind. These changes along with other roadmap items should more effectively mitigate any value capture prior to collapse. 

Please note that these changes will be forward-looking and will not affect your prior positions. If your position is still open at the time of release, you will be allowed to gracefully transition your position to the new leverage limits, the details of which may be found in the proposal.

Proposal: https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p5/

> This will also allow us to further extend the timeout period where a miner's incentive is set to 0 for crossing 5% mdd.

@raphel [ 𝞃 , 𝞃 ] MDD is calculated against your portfolio value of all time, so it doesn't reset after 30 days. If you have 5% MDD and do nothing for 30 days, you will still have 5% MDD. In our calculation for risk adjusted return, we look at the largest max drawdown seen from the miner over the prior 30 days and use this to determine the normalization factor, regardless of your current portfolio value or current max drawdown. Our effective "memory" of max drawdown events for scoring will increase when we extend the time horizon for the checkpoints.

We have no plans to decay the max drawdown over time, although happy to take feedback on the MDD penalty as we extend the time horizon.

MDD penalty will not affected, and will change decay period from 30 to 60 days
> The potency of raw return will decrease by about 50% in ~~18~~ 36 hours, while the potency of gains and losses used to calculate the risk metrics will decay by 50% in around ~~22~~ 44 days.

@ptn・8 We would like to propose a slight modification to proposal four, which introduces a new fee structure to accommodate the cost of carry. Our initial proposal suggested setting fee rates at approximately 60% of our researched annual figures to account for potential real-world discrepancies, such as periods when funding rates are positive. However, upon further investigation and analysis of the impact on miner scores, we think the numbers should be slightly more aggressive to apply more appropriate downward pressure on positions. As such, we propose that the fees should be increased to 100% of the researched rates to start.

Given our relatively short time window for measuring miner performance, the number of closed positions and touch points are incredibly useful for evaluating miner strategy. Therefore, we feel that higher carry fees will provide better insight into miner strategy by applying appropriate downward pressure to close positions.

The updated fees will be as follows:
- Forex: 1.75% -> 3.0%
- Crypto: 8% -> 10.95%
- Indices: 3% -> 5.25%

A couple of reminders:
- We use the maximum leverage seen for each market fee period to determine the fee on the position. You can avoid these fees by closing your position before the fee accrual time.
- This will be a forward-looking update and will only start impacting miner positions at the point of release.

The updated proposal can be seen here, the tentative timeline for release is this Friday, July 12:
https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p4/

@ptn・8  We are releasing a new proposal, P6, which outlines an update to the scoring system. This update will significantly increase the significance of long-term returns. This aligns with our roadmap item “Predictability as Priority,” as our miners with the highest long-term returns have demonstrated their strategies more effectively. By keeping these miners ranked relatively high, the network model will be able to follow their positions more closely and mirror their returns. The function of short-term returns will also shift, moving from the main driver of the score to a motivational piece for miners to regularly engage with the platform.

Another major introduction in this proposal is a clean-up of the logic for the consistency penalty. Consistency score will now be determined based on how much of your current value change over 30 days came from just one checkpoint period. This update brings it in line with new constraints on leverage and helps track consistency against the historical ups and downs of the miner.

Other smaller changes in this PR, outlined in the proposal:
* Removal of Augmentation to simpler logic
* Three day window for short term returns
* Update of the dashboard values for augmented statistics, incorporating penalties
* Cleanup of scoring logic with the exponential distribution to remove high drawdown miners

Thank you @kabar  for bringing miner percentiles into focus, which helped us iron this out! We will continue to monitor changes in miner behavior following this rollout, and may continue to propose tweaks as needed to encourage future predictability.

Proposal: https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p6/ 
PR: https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/pull/289 
Integration Date: July 17, 2024

This is really great @Terps , you’re touching on some important philosophical questions as to what we want to build. We want to incentivize high quality trading signals. We also want to translate these signals into actionable trades for our end users. A mechanism of balancing returns from closed positions with unrealized gains will do this, and will help to articulate the value of our traders using traditional metrics on closed positions. A single buy and hold trader could still provide valuable signal only in one direction, they would just need to occasionally close the position to balance the ratio of unrealized and realized gains which would give us a touchpoint for closed position metrics.

Per trade risk / return is something important I think we’ll likely explore down the road, and we might step into using other position based metrics albeit slowly as risk adjusted returns will remain the priority. I’ll outline all of this with more detail in the upcoming proposal and attach the PR for your reference, looking forward to the feedback on it.

@ptn・8  We’re releasing P7, which introduces a position based penalty and a change from exponential distribution of incentive to a softmax based approach. Your miners will now track similarity between realized and unrealized returns, and you will receive a penalty if there is a substantial discrepancy between the two. Additionally, we will look at your profile of returns, and penalize you if most of your overall return is attributable to a single position. Finally, switching from exponential decay to softmax will allow us to be more dynamic with incentive, distributing more accurately to miners based on their performance and enabling the top miner to push further towards the top if they continue to improve their score.

A brief summary of updated tips that you will want to consider to score well in PTN as a trader:

* Have some level of trading activity on our platform for at least 2 weeks.
* Avoid concentrating all returns for the month on just one day of trading, at a bare minimum spread them through the day.
* [new] Close positions any time your unrealized returns over the prior look-back period (30 days) changes by 10% or more to keep your realized and unrealized returns in sync.
* [new] Open and close at least 5-10 positions per month.
* [new] Keep positions relatively short, ideally less than three days per position.
* [new] Avoid having all of your returns concentrated on one position. If this is your current situation, try to close more trades which balance the distribution of returns to more positions.

We are targeting an integration date of Aug 2, 2024, which hopefully provides enough time for public dialogue and feedback. We also recommend that you start considering the new positional criteria in your mining strategies, to ensure a smoother transition in case you are currently violating one of the criteria.

Proposal: https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p7/
PR: https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/pull/299

There are so many things this proposal overlooks, I would really just recommend switching to evaluating everything on the position level entirely if this is the direction you guy move towards.  The more constraints you add like this the more the subnet becomes gaming the constraints instead of developing actual strategies, you will just see more of the high win rate / high volume of trades miners that tend to blow up.

Stuff like this shouldn't be implemented in a weeks notice, there should be at least the same duration of notice as the look back period.
Thanks for reviewing and bringing up these points. We will definitely push back the timeline to allow more thinking and iteration on this relatively large change.

We can definitely push the time horizon back with the proposal, if it helps miners better transition. For context to new miners/ members of the community, we used to score miners only based on closed positions. A major  challenge with this was that miners would often reduce leverage on open positions to small values for losing positions, avoiding dropping their realized returns by never taking a losing position. We adopted a realtime portfolio value approach after this, which scores the miners based on their unrealized returns.

Even if we switch entirely to positions based penalties, we will need some realtime metric to penalize losing positions. This will incentivize miners to close losing positions if they believe the value may decrease further. We would likely still have some protocol to penalize the discrepancy between realized and unrealized returns, and we would want to rearchitect the risk metric to be position based (drawdown).

@Terps it sounds like a concern is that longer positions will have a disadvantage with the new system, when their return / risk profile is identical. This is true, and a good point. However, higher frequency trades give us more information about the miner’s strategy earlier into the period, which increases our confidence in their aptitude. For any realized returns scoring metric we use, shorter positions would likely have an advantage as long as we have a look back period.

Increasing the look back period (we will soon transition from 30 to 90) will further reduce any discrepancies between shorter and longer trades, and we could also consider reducing the intensity of the realized/unrealized ratio penalty to avoid it becoming a primary mechanism of scoring well if it’s an issue.

Really appreciate the feedback and think it’s a good thought, just wanted to provide a bit of context on what a potential deeper change would require

'However, higher frequency trades give us more information about the miner’s strategy earlier into the period, which increases our confidence in their aptitude'
A trade that is open for 30 days then closed provides the same information as the same trade that is open and closed every day in a 30 day period.
